verses.verse: There was a certain man who was weak, Lazarus, out of Bethany, from the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
Mary was the woman who dabbed perfume on the Master and wiped His feet dry with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was weak.
So the sisters sent someone out to Him, saying, "Master, look, a person whom You are fond of is weak."
When Jesus heard, He said, "This weakness is not to death, but on behalf of the magnificence of God, so that the Son of God might be made magnificent through it."
Jesus was loving Martha, her sister, and Lazarus.
So as He heard that he is weak, at that time, He certainly stayed in a place where He was two days.
Following after this, He says to the students, "We may lead into Judea again."
The students say to Him, "Rabbi, the Jewish people now were looking to attack You with stones, and You are going back there again?"
Jesus answered, "Are there not twelve hours of the day? If anyone traipses around during the day, he doesn't stumble because he sees the light of this world.
But if anyone traipses around in the night, he stumbles because the light is not in him."
He said these things, and after this He says to them, "Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep, but I am traveling there so that I might wake him up."
So His students said, "Master, if he has fallen asleep, he will be rescued."
Jesus had stated about his death, but to those students it seemed that He is talking about the sleep of the slumber.
So at that time, Jesus said to them openly, "Lazarus died,
and I am happy because of you (so that you might trust) that I wasn't there, but we may lead toward him."
So Thomas (the one called Twin) said to his fellow students, "We may also lead so that we might die with him."
So when Jesus came, He found him already having four days in the burial vault.
Bethany was near Greater Jerusalem, as if it were fifteen track laps (almost 2 miles) away.
Many from the Jewish people had come to the women around Martha and Mary so that they might comfort them concerning their brother.
So Martha, as she heard that Jesus is coming, went to meet with Him. But Mary was seated in the house.
So Martha said to Jesus, "Master, if You were here, my brother wouldn't have died.
But I realize even now that however many things that you ask God for, God will give to You."
Jesus says to her, "Your brother will come back to life again."
Martha says to Him, "I realize that he will come back to life again in the return back to life in the last day."
Jesus said to her, "I am the Return Back to Life and the Life. The person trusting in Me, even if he were dead, he will live.
And everyone living and trusting in Me will not in any way die for the span of time. Do you trust this?"
She says to Him, "Yes, Master. I have trusted that You are the Anointed King, the Son of God, the One coming into the world."
And after she said these things, she went away and hollered in an unnoticed way for Mary, her sister, when she said, "The Teacher is beside us and is hollering for you."
That sister, as she heard, gets up quickly and goes to Him.
Jesus hadn't yet come into the village, but was in the place where Martha went to meet Him.

So the Jewish people, the ones who were with her in the house and were comforting her, when they saw that Mary quickly got up and went out, followed her, saying that she is going back to the burial vault so that she might cry there.
So Mary, as she came to where Jesus was, when she saw Him, fell to His feet, saying to Him, "Master, if You were here, my brother would not have died."
So Jesus, as He saw her crying and the Jewish people who came together with her crying, was stern in the spirit and agitated Himself.
And He said, "Where have you put him?" They say to Him, "Master, come and see."
Jesus teared up.
So the Jewish people were saying, "Look, how fond He was of him!"
But some from among them said, "Wasn't this Man, the One who opened the eyes of the blind, able to make it so that this man also would not die?"
So Jesus again being stern in Himself comes to the burial vault. It was a cave and a stone was lying on it.
Jesus says, "Take the stone away." The sister of the one who had died, Martha, says to Him, "Master, he already stinks. You see, he is a four-day-old corpse."
Jesus says to her, "Didn't I tell you that if you trust, you will see the magnificence of God?"
So they took the stone away from where the one that had died was lying. Jesus raised up His eyes and said, "Father, I thank You that You listened to Me.
I knew that You always listen to Me, but because of the crowd, the one that has stood around, I said it so that they might trust that You sent Me out on a mission."
And after saying these things, He made a yell with a loud voice, "Lazarus, come here outside."

The one who had died came out having been tied up (the feet and the hands) with strips of cloth, and his eyes had a towel tied around them. Jesus says to them, "Release him, and leave him to be going back home."
So many from the Jewish people, the ones who came to Mary and saw what Jesus did, trusted in Him.
But some from among them went off to the Separatists and told them things that Jesus did.
So the head priests and the Separatists gathered a council together and were saying, "What do we do? Because this Person is doing many indicators.
If we leave Him like this, everyone will trust in Him, and the Romans will come and take away both our place and nation."
A certain one from among them, Caiaphas, who was the head priest that year, said to them, "You don't know anything.
Neither are you thoroughly considering that it is advantageous to us that one person die on behalf of the ethnic group and the whole nation not be ruined."
This he didn't say out from himself, but being a head priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus was going to be dying on behalf of the nation,
and not just on behalf of the nation, but so that He might also gather the children of God (the ones that had been dispersed) together into one.
So from that day they together advised that they should kill Him.

So Jesus was no longer traipsing around openly among the Jewish people, but He went away from there into the rural area near the backcountry into a city called Ephraim. And He was spending time there with His students.
The Passover of the Jewish people was near, and many walked up to Jerusalem from the rural area before the Passover so that they might consecrate themselves.
So they were looking for Jesus and were talking with each other (who had stood on the temple grounds), "What? Does it seem to you that He won't in any way come to the festival?"
Both the head priests and the Separatists had given a demand that if anyone knew where He is, He should disclose it in order that they might arrest Him.
